subtitle: recently i was scrolling through old

i took the picture and held it up to my

wow i look nothing like that kid in the
picture
we don't have the same physical
properties our thoughts ideas and
beliefs are different
and we certainly don't have the same
memories
but still
i know it's me
my brain sees the picture and creates a
storyline that i was there i am here and
i'll be somewhere else in the future
looking back doing the same exact thing
this is the idea of self the idea that
there's something deep within us that
remains fundamentally the same even when
everything else changes
it's the idea that we can grow bigger
create new memories lose old memories
change our thoughts and beliefs but deep
down there's still something that
remains fundamentally unchanged
the idea of self is one that has baffled
pretty much everyone scientists and
philosophers alike for centuries
because as easy as it is to describe

on the opposite end of the spectrum as
humans we experience a lot of different
senses
we feel things we see things and we hear
things we have thoughts we have feelings

things
but all of these things are separate
experiences
so
at what point do all of these sentient
properties become
you
as i continued scrolling through the

everything after
all these photos looked completely

when i think back to those times and the

yet without a shadow of a doubt
my brain convinces me that i am still me
the words i and me are more than just
pronouns they are the two ways we
describe self
when we say i we talk about a being who
is consciously aware of the present
moment
so i am reading this line on a script
right now
on the other hand when we describe self

referring to a personal identity who we
think we are
me usually reflects who we are through

but we color our memories based on what

how can there be a consistent being if
everything that forms it changes
we like to think of memories as simply
playing back a video in our head of what

but that's not what memories are
memories are our brain's reconstruction
of the past experiences
we create these memories to fit the
present narrative based on what we know
now how we describe me now as well as
our present needs and goals
so if you now think of yourself as a
kind person you're more likely to

we form narratives about ourselves

we convince ourselves that we'll act and

narrative
even when we're often mistaken
if this is true and we can't trust our

aren't we just creating new selves every

think about it it's not that the

path it changes completely such that
what was no longer is
and if what was can no longer be
then we cannot say that there is a self

rather the idea of self is one that is

this is what we refer to as the illusion
of self
contrary to what you might be thinking
this does not mean that we don't have a

it simply means that it does not exist

our bodies are made up of a bundle of

our brains try to make sense of the

it is this storyline of sorts that we

it's just the brain's way of making

this is why the idea of self that we

the self is a sensation of continuity

thinking that humans are more than just

the idea that deep down we have a soul

and in most religions of the world
this is true

anata is the buddhist doctrine that

material wealth can't belong to me

so

the truth is

we learn adapt we grow

without competition we'll all be

without the illusion of self there is no

competition is built on the idea of a

if there is no single entity and just

things just don't really work the way

if you're still not convinced that the

our brains make up the idea of a unified
